history: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal. It took over 20 years to complete, with construction starting in 1632 and finishing in 1653. The monument is considered one of the most beautiful examples of Mughal architecture. It is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site and attracts millions of visitors each year.
Ecological Relevance: The Taj Mahal is located on the banks of the Yamuna River in Agra, India. Its gardens and surrounding landscape contribute to the local ecosystem and biodiversity. However, pollution and industrial activity in the area have caused concerns about damage to the monument's marble facade.

timeline.Details: Construction of the Taj Mahal begins.
Mumtaz Mahal, the wife of Shah Jahan, dies during childbirth.
Construction of the Taj Mahal is completed.
The Taj Mahal is designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Taj Mahal is declared a winner of the New7Wonders of the World initiative.
Indian authorities implement measures to combat pollution and preserve the Taj Mahal.
